item.title: Lamp Blog
item.description:
This is my first blog so hopefully it's engaging and interesting enough. So, why did I make this lamp? When people ask me why I make stuff, I tend to answer "Why not?" But in this case I had good reason to be making it. My current desk lamp at the time was on the fritz and I'd had the idea for a while to make a lamp that helps me wake up for early mornings. The idea is to have this lamp slowly increase brightness to emulate a sunrise on days when I need to wake up before the sun has risen.
This is a blog about the design and prototyping of a lamp I made in order to help me get up for early morning classes.
Simply from a few tests without the lamp, I feel like it is actually helping considerably. On days without the lamp, I wake up to just my alarm blaring and I struggle to even comprehend how to snooze it. But with the lamp, I wake up much more easily and feeling more refreshed.
Keeping in mind, I only use the lamp for days I have to wake up before the sun has also woken up.

Started with the base where the boards are mounted
First modeled the bounds of the boards

For the sake of efficiency and just to get some practice, I decided to go with a constant current supply rather than the typically used current limiting resistor design

Initially I'd started writing the software for the STM32 completely from scratch in bare metal C with no help libraries (I was not sane). The first version of the lamp which I used for a year used these handwritten libraries. I then switched to using libopencm3 for a more robust and WAY faster development (I'm still not sane, I know).
Talk about terminal interface as well

Used a very large heavy iron tip for large thermal mass (easier to work with the big copper heatsink)
Flattened spots on wire heatsink for each led
Made sure flattened spots all point in same direction
Applied some solder to back of each led where it would normally attach to a heatsink

RTC battery
brightness potentiometer
